report_section_templates.title: Disclaimer and Reading Guide
report_section_templates.writing_guide:
This part provides guidance to the reader on how to interpret the report contents.

Include:
- Statement that findings are based on materials delivered and discovered during investigation
- Timestamp format explanation (UTC, ISO 8601)
- Statements of probability scale (1-10% = Very Unlikely, 11-40% = Unlikely, 41-60% = Even Chance, 61-90% = Likely, 90-99% = Very Likely)
- Statements of confidence (High/Medium/Low)
- How "Investigator's Interpretation" sections should be read
report_section_templates.template_content:
This report has been written based on the facts found during an investigation into a cyber security incident. The investigation conclusions and findings are based on the materials delivered for inspection and discovered during the investigation. All findings in this report are subject to change if new evidence is discovered or presented to the investigation team.

## Timestamps

Unless otherwise stated, all timestamps are presented in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) following the ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ.

## Statements of Probability

| Chance | Statement                           |
| ------ | ----------------------------------- |
|  1-10% | Very Unlikely, Almost certainly not |
| 11-40% | Unlikely, Improbable                |
| 41-60% | Even Chance                         |
| 61-90% | Probably, Likely                    |
| 90-99% | Very Likely, Almost Certainly       |

## Statements of Confidence

- **High Confidence**: Evidence strongly supports the statement with no contrary evidence
- **Medium Confidence**: Evidence supports the statement but other evidence could surface
- **Low Confidence**: Missing evidence, major questions unanswered

report_section_templates.title: Intended Audience
report_section_templates.writing_guide:
Describe who this report is written for and what level of technical detail they should expect.

Consider:
- Technical vs. non-technical readers
- Management vs. operational staff
- Internal vs. external stakeholders

report_section_templates.title: Executive Summary
report_section_templates.writing_guide:
A clear and concise summary of the event, excluding technical details unless absolutely necessary.

Guidelines:
- Written for a business audience with no assumed technical expertise
- Should be written LAST, after all other reporting is done
- Target length: less than one printed page
- Start with the most critical information: nature of incident, impact, steps taken
- Include: key findings, incident summary, remediation recommendations
- Include metrics: time from detection to resolution, economic impacts where measurable

Example opening: "Our investigation revealed a data breach that compromised sensitive information of 500 users, prompting immediate remediation actions and enhanced security protocols."

report_section_templates.title: Business Impact Analysis
report_section_templates.writing_guide:
Assess the potential implications of the incident on the organization's operations.

Structure:
1. **Immediate Impact**: Unauthorized access, service disruption, malware propagation
2. **Short-Term Consequences**: Financial losses, data breach risk, loss of trust
3. **Long-Term Ramifications**: Reputational damage, customer attrition, regulatory consequences

Include recommendations for immediate actions and long-term resilience strategies.

report_section_templates.title: Investigation Limitations
report_section_templates.writing_guide:
All investigations have limitations. Document them here.

Common limitations:
- Log retention periods (suggest PCI DSS: 90 days indexed, 365 days cold storage)
- Unavailable endpoints or devices
- Time constraints from customer
- Wiped or destroyed evidence
- Missing forensic images
- Incomplete AV/EDR coverage

This chapter can include recommendations for ensuring evidence availability in future incidents.

report_section_templates.title: Investigation Goals and Research Questions
report_section_templates.writing_guide:
The goals of the investigation formulated as research questions.

Research questions guide the investigation and are answered in the conclusions.

Example questions:
- What was the initial point of entry to the network?
  - Subquestion: What method was used to gain initial access?
- Which credentials are suspected of being compromised?
- Are there any signs of data exfiltration?
- Was personal data compromised?
  - Subquestion: How many records were compromised?
  - Subquestion: Which regulatory environment applies?

report_section_templates.title: Investigation Details
report_section_templates.writing_guide:
This is the main chapter of the report. Describe the investigation method, actions taken, outcomes, and how the incident was resolved.

Guidelines:
- Break into subchapters for individual "subplots" (compromised accounts, endpoints, malware analysis)
- If a section runs several pages, break it into parts
- Use monospace font for `usernames`, `servernames`, `ip addresses`, and `software`
- Use code blocks for lists of IP addresses
- Long lists belong in attachments, not inline

Example structure:
## 4.1 Account Compromise for admin01
### 4.1.1 Initial Access on Admin Endpoint
### 4.1.2 Privilege Escalation Attempts
### 4.1.3 RDP Password Spraying Attacks

## 4.2 Attacker Activities on XMPL-DC02
### 4.2.1 Lateral Movement
### 4.2.2 Compromised Credentials

## 4.3 Indicators of Compromise

report_section_templates.title: Conclusions and Recommendations
report_section_templates.writing_guide:
Carry the conclusions of the investigation and recommendations for improvement.

## Conclusions
- Take original research questions and answer them based on facts
- Address unanswered questions (reference limitations chapter)
- Be careful with certainty and culpability statements
- Describe what an *account* did, not what a *user* did (factual, provable)
- Remain neutral and technical

## Recommendations
- Based on conclusions and your security expertise
- Focus on preventing similar incidents
- Must be grounded in concrete findings
- Be specific enough to be actionable
- General recommendations ("do security better") are not useful
- Actionable recommendations ("monitor and block open RDP ports") are useful

report_section_templates.title: Style Guide
report_section_templates.writing_guide: This section is a general style guide and is not meant to be included in the report.
report_section_templates.template_content:
# General Style Guide

1. Use clear, simple and careful language.
2. Avoid overly long or overly short sentences.
3. State only facts in the text body, leave the interpretations and conclusions to the "investigators interpretation" paragraphs.
4. Do not try to explain what a user did, explain instead what the user _account_ was observed doing.
5. Use a monospace font for all technical indicators, including program names, IP addresses, URLs, computer names, network locations, etc.
6. Use item references where reasonable to tie the text to evidence items
7. If a key item is being referenced in the report, add it as an evidence item first, then use the reference in the report.
8. Present malicious or suspicious URL and IP's in a defanged format: hxxps://www[.]evilsite[.]com[:]8080.
9. Use a light background colour when taking screenshots. Disable dark mode for screenshots. Reports are often printed.
10. Use screenshots when possible. Remember that text in screenshots is not searchable, so copy-paste the text contents alongside the screenshot if possible. Attach screenshots to the case and use references to bring them in the report body.
11. Mask out personal information in the embedded image files using solid masks that are a part of the image file.
12. If a table or chart spans several pages, move it to an attachment. Instead of presenting the table, explain the table contents and refer to the attachment for full details.
13. When explaining anything that takes more than two steps, draw a diagram, attach it to the case and reference it in the report body.
14. When attaching live malware samples, add a warning and compress the malware sample using password protection. Define the password in the report. If no password is specified, use default "`infected`" as the password. Some security tools will decrypt zip files with the default password and remove the malware sample, so using a different password is recommended.
15. Use [Markdown syntax](https://www.markdownguide.org/basic-syntax/) to keep the report portable.
